factoid: Prince Andrew's joyous feeling weakened as he approached the door of the Minister of War's room.
Prince Andrew felt offended.
The feeling of offense immediately turned into a feeling of disdain.
The feeling of disdain was uncalled for.
Prince Andrew's fertile mind suggested a point of view that gave him a right to despise the adjutant and the Minister of War.
Prince Andrew thought that away from the smell of powder, the adjutant and the Minister of War probably think it easy to gain victories.
Prince Andrew's eyes narrowed disdainfully.
Prince Andrew entered the room of the Minister of War with peculiarly deliberate steps.
The feeling of disdain was heightened when Prince Andrew saw the Minister of War seated at a large table reading papers and making pencil notes.
For the first two or three minutes the Minister of War took no notice of Prince Andrew's arrival.
A wax candle stood at each side of the Minister of War's bent bald head with its gray temples.
The Minister of War continued reading until the end without raising his eyes at the opening of the door or the sound of footsteps.
Prince Andrew said, “Take this and deliver it,” to his adjutant.
Prince Andrew handed the papers to his adjutant.
Prince Andrew still took no notice of the special messenger.
Prince Andrew felt that the actions of Kutúzov’s army interested the Minister of War less than any of the other matters he was concerned with.
Prince Andrew felt that he wanted to give the Russian special messenger that impression.
Prince Andrew thought, “But that is a matter of perfect indifference to me.”
The Minister of War drew the remaining papers together and arranged them evenly.
The Minister of War raised his head.
The Minister of War had an intellectual and distinctive head.
When the Minister of War turned to Prince Andrew, the firm, intelligent expression on his face changed deliberately and habitually.
The Minister of War's face took on a stupid artificial smile that does not attempt to hide its artificiality.
The Minister of War is a man who continually receives many petitioners one after another.
The Minister of War asked, “From General Field Marshal Kutúzov?”
The Minister of War asked, “I hope it is good news?”
The Minister of War asked, “There has been an encounter with Mortier?”
The Minister of War asked, “A victory?”
The Minister of War said, “It was high time!”
The Minister of War took the dispatch addressed to him.
The Minister of War began to read the dispatch with a mournful expression.
The Minister of War exclaimed in German, “Oh, my God! My God! Schmidt!”
The Minister of War said, “What a calamity! What a calamity!”
The Minister of War glanced through the dispatch.
The Minister of War laid the dispatch on the table.
The Minister of War looked at Prince Andrew, evidently considering something.
The Minister of War said, “Ah what a calamity! You say the affair was decisive? But Mortier is not captured.”
The Minister of War pondered again.
The Minister of War said, “I am very glad you have brought good news, though Schmidt’s death is a heavy price to pay for the victory.”
The Minister of War said, “His Majesty will no doubt wish to see you, but not today.”
The Minister of War said, “I thank you!”
The Minister of War said, “You must have a rest.”
The Minister of War said, “Be at the levee tomorrow after the parade.”
The Minister of War said, “However, I will let you know.”
The Minister of War's stupid smile reappeared.
The Minister of War added, “Au revoir! Thank you very much. His Majesty will probably desire to see you,” and bowed his head.
When Prince Andrew left the palace, he felt that all the interest and happiness the victory had afforded him had now been left in the indifferent hands of the Minister of War and the polite adjutant.
The whole tenor of Prince Andrew's thoughts instantaneously changed.
The battle seemed to Prince Andrew the memory of a remote event long past.
Prince Andrew stayed at Brünn with Bilíbin, a Russian acquaintance of Prince Andrew in the diplomatic service.
Bilíbin said, “Ah, my dear prince! I could not have a more welcome visitor,” as he came out to meet Prince Andrew.
Bilíbin said to the servant Franz, “Put the prince’s things in my bedroom.”
Bilíbin said, “So you’re a messenger of victory, eh? Splendid! And I am sitting here ill, as you see.”
After washing and dressing, Prince Andrew came into Bilíbin's luxurious study and sat down to the dinner prepared for him.
Bilíbin settled down comfortably beside the fire.

After his journey and the campaign during which he had been deprived of all the comforts of cleanliness and all the refinements of life, Prince Andrew felt a pleasant sense of repose among luxurious surroundings such as he had been accustomed to from childhood.

It was pleasant for Prince Andrew after his reception by the Austrians to speak, if not in Russian, at least with a Russian who would share the general Russian antipathy to the Austrians which was then particularly strong.
